column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=What 's the interpretation of that , translation of that mean ?
#Text=Casa particular .
#Text=Like a rooming house ?
#Text=Like a rooming house .
#Text=Exactly .
#Text=Or like a Bed and Breakfast ?
#Text=That 's probably the best analogy .
#Text=Staying at those
#Text=the money goes more to the people .
#Text=The other thing they tell you when you go to Cuba is to bring aspirin and all these things that are in short supply there .
#Text=The people who run these Bed and Breakfasts , if you will , make out with all the stuff the tourists give them to be dispersed in their communities .
#Text=I went to Ecuador .
#Text=I went camping in the Amazon .
#Text=These are the places that interest me now .
#Text=Do you find it similar in your own travels to really seek out things underneath , to pull up rocks and try and find places off the beaten path .
#Text=Going to Timbuktu or wherever .
#Text=Do you have a travel philosophy ?
#Text=Well since we 're talking about Cuba , it was only four weeks in 1982 in which I traveled in Cuba to baseball towns .
#Text=My idea often is to go to places with the announced notion of dealing with almost inconsequential parts of society .
#Text=In China it was women 's soccer .
#Text=In Cuba , when I went first in ' 82 , it was the idea of writing about sports fans and baseball games .
#Text=The idea was to get me out of Havana .
#Text=The only way I was going to get freedom , certainly nothing political .
#Text=But if you 're writing about baseball fans in Cuba , it means you can go to towns , sit in the stands ... .
#Text=And talk to the people .
#Text=The people , how they get there , how they 're dressed , how they behave and really observe a lot of people because the town , four or five baseball towns .
#Text=They 're big .
#Text=And you can travel around the country .
#Text=‘ Where are you going ? '
#Text=‘ We 're going to the baseball game .
#Text=' You always can explain yourself .
#Text=And I was very impressed in ' 82 .
#Text=When I went back , I was writing a story I published called " Ali in Havana . "
#Text=It 's in a collection of mine called The Gay Talese Reader , but it was published in Esquire in ‘ 96 .
#Text=Since you mentioned medical supplies , I went back to accompany Muhammed Ali on a private jet that left Miami for Havana .
#Text=He and about twenty people were on that plane able to circumvent the embargo because he was on a humanitarian mission , or at least convinced the government authorities in Washington he was .
#Text=He got clearance because of who he is .
#Text=And he took medical supplies down .
#Text=But he , himself , was so sick with Parkinson 's .
#Text=At the time , I did n't realize how unable to communicate I would be with him because I could n't hear him .
#Text=He did n't make any sense .
#Text=But that did n't matter because I do n't really write Q&A kind of stuff anyway .
#Text=Just hanging around with him was fine .
#Text=But I was able to see a lot of the Cuban people .

#Text=I was able to go to the medical facilities , hospitals and clinics to see nurses , see doctors , get a look at the interior of the medical quarters of the doctors and how the patients were dressed and what kind of equipment was around in a medical sense .
#Text=I was very impressed by the resources of the people .

#Text=Despite the attempts by such hostile nations as the U.S. toward Cuba , despite the embargo and all the other restraints and restrictions , to say nothing of the assassination attempts on Castro himself , people were very strong and , as you suggested , it 's a very egalitarian society and I was with a lot of black people who were part of the contingent of Ali .
